content: How can I help you today?

I'm not sure where to start. My wife and I have been struggling at home, mostly because our son has been having these behavioral issues, and it's starting to take a toll on everything—my marriage, my work, even spending time with my daughter. I just feel overwhelmed and don't really know what to do anymore.

You’re managing so much right now—your son’s behavior, the impact on your family, your marriage, your work, and your time with your daughter. Feeling overwhelmed makes sense with everything happening all at once. What’s been the hardest part for you in all of this?

I think the hardest part is feeling like I'm failing everyone—my son, my wife, my daughter, even myself. No matter how much I try or how much effort I put into fixing things, nothing seems to get better. It’s like I’m stuck in this cycle, and I don’t know how to break out of it.

It sounds like you're carrying a lot of responsibility and a deep sense of care for your family. Feeling stuck in that cycle can be exhausting, especially when it feels like your efforts aren’t bringing the change you hope for. What keeps you going during all of this?

Honestly, it's my family. As much as everything feels like it's falling apart, I keep pushing because I want to help my son, support my wife, and be there for my daughter. I want to keep us together—it’s just hard to see how to make that happen right now.

Your commitment to your family shines through, even as you navigate these tough times. Caring so deeply for them is a powerful reason to keep moving forward, even when it feels heavy. What would "keeping your family together" look like to you?

I think it would mean getting to a place where we can all enjoy being with each other again—less tension, fewer fights, and actually feeling like we're connected as a family. I want to see my son doing better, my wife and I being a team again, and having time to just be there for my daughter too. Right now, it feels like everyone's pulling away, and I don’t know how to bring us back together.

You're holding onto a vision of connection and togetherness that’s deeply meaningful to you. Bringing your family back to that place sounds like it would bring hope and peace for everyone. What do you think might help you start moving toward that vision?

I honestly don’t even know where to start. Maybe understanding how to help my son would make a difference, or finding a way for my wife and I to feel like we’re on the same page again. I’m just not sure how to approach any of it.

It makes sense that starting feels hard when there are so many layers to untangle—helping your son, strengthening your bond with your wife, and creating harmony for your family. It sounds like each step matters to you. What small but meaningful action do you feel ready to explore first?

I guess I’d want to start with my son. If we can figure out what’s going on with him and how to really help, maybe the rest of us could have a little breathing room to work on everything else. But I don’t even know where to begin with him.

Focusing on your son feels like an important first step for you. Wanting to understand what’s going on with him shows how much you care and want to support him. What has he been struggling with most, and how has it been affecting him and your family?

He’s been acting out a lot—tantrums, not listening, getting into trouble at school. It’s like he’s angry all the time, but when we try to talk to him, he either shuts down or explodes. It’s causing so much tension at home, and we just don’t know how to reach him.

It sounds like your son’s behaviors are signaling that he's dealing with some big feelings, and trying to talk to him hasn’t been easy for anyone. Navigating the anger and shutting down can feel discouraging and overwhelming for both you and your wife. How do you think he's feeling during these moments, and how do you usually respond?

It feels like he’s frustrated and overwhelmed too, but he doesn’t know how to express it without acting out. When he starts shutting down or exploding, I usually either try to calm him down or sometimes I lose my patience and get frustrated myself. It’s not how I want to handle it, but I don’t know what else to do in the moment.

You’re doing your best in a really challenging situation, and it’s clear you care deeply about supporting him, even when frustration takes over. The moments you try to calm him reflect your desire to help. What do you think he needs from you during those times?

Maybe he needs me to reassure him that I’m there for him, even when he’s upset. But honestly, it’s hard to stay calm when he’s losing it—it feels like no matter what I try, it just escalates. I don’t know how to break that pattern.

Breaking that pattern sounds like a big challenge when emotions are running so high—for both of you. Wanting to reassure him and be there shows how much you want to connect, even in tough moments. What do you think might help you stay grounded when he’s upset?

Maybe if I could remind myself that he’s not trying to make things harder on purpose, it would help me stay calmer. It’s just, in the moment, it all feels so overwhelming, and I get caught up in my own frustration. I guess I need strategies to handle it better.

Recognizing that he’s not intentionally trying to make things harder is such an insightful thought—it reflects your empathy for what he might be going through. Finding ways to stay grounded amidst that frustration could give you more room to respond how you want. Would you like to explore strategies together, or is there anything else you’d like to talk about first?
